Award.AwardTitle: OPES (Open-source Problems in Engineering Studies): Making the WeB WorK

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project is expanding the WeBWork homework delivery tool into engineering. It generates a repository of WeBWorK engineering problems for three core, semester-long, sophomore-level engineering courses: Statics and Mechanics of Materials, Electrical Engineering and Circuits, and Thermodynamics. The problem library is being made available worldwide for free public utilization. The project includes a research component to study the effect of online engineering homework on student learning.

Due to the electronic nature of the freely available repository, this project has the potential to impact students and faculty from a broad range of schools, including minority institutions, community colleges and non-PhD-granting institutions. The project builds on the success of WeBWorK in mathematics and expands it to engineering. The project team continues to embrace the open-source concept as a means to expand the project and disseminate results, thereby enhancing infrastructure in engineering education. A project website is being created and maintained, which updates the engineering community about assessment studies, journal publications, and training opportunities. In addition to in-house training, a two-day workshop is being hosted for ten external participants, and a workshop is being offered at an American Society for Engineering Education annual meeting. The research and assessment from this project has the potential to shape future directions in engineering education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

OPES (Open-source Problems in Engineering Studies): Making the WeB WorK set out to create 405 online homework problems for free distribution and adoption through the open-source homework system WeBWorK for three core engineering courses: Statics and Mechanics of Materials (125), Circuits (200), and Thermodynamics (80). The project met and exceeded this objective with the creation of over 550 problems for these three courses as well as an advanced mechanics of materials course. All problems were developed to be compatible with self-contained, interpolated property data tables and are, therefore, independent of any specific textbook.

This project also set out to conduct an educational research study to examine the effects of online homework, as compared to traditional paper and pencil homework, on student learning. The educational research study has resulted in four peer-reviewed conference publications, and further data is set to be analyzed and published after the project conclusion.

Broader Impacts

Over 475 of the homework problems have been tested repeatedly at Louisiana Tech University and project partner Bossier Parish Community College and disseminated to the Open Problem Library for broad dissemination. The remaining problems will be tested again with another student cohort and then disseminated to the Open Problem Library at a later time.

The statistical analyses of the data collected as part of the research students suggest that students completing online homework administered through the open-source WeBWorK system learn course content as well as, and in some cases better than, students completing traditional paper homework. The online WeBWorK homework in engineering supports efficient use of faculty time and university resources without a sacrifice to student learning. Furthermore, student feedback regarding this homework system is positive relative to other homework methods, largely because students tend to appreciate the instant feedback it provides regarding the correctness of their answers.

Four peer-reviewed conference publications were presented at American Society for Engineering Education annual meetings. Additionally, the project team led a workshop for new engineering WeBWorK faculty users at the American Society for Engineering Education annual meeting in June 2015. This dissemination has resulted in numerous conversations with and inquiries from faculty at other universities interested in engineering WeBWorK. Access to three courses of homework problems (475), along with course hosting offers, were provided independently of the Open Problem Library to roughly 15 faculty from other universities not already part of this grant. The Electrical Engineering Department at the University of Connecticut implemented the Louisiana Tech circuits WeBWorK problems in all of their first circuits courses in the Spring 2017 semester, and Louisiana Tech University hosted this course free of charge for approximately 250 University of Connecticut students.
